reviews.review_msg: Came into this course not expecting much but it actually turned out pretty interesting! Professor Begby is nice and he posts lecture notes for each lecture too, which helped a lot. Course consisted of two papers, participation, and a take-home final, which was alright and mainly got you to more thoroughly analyze some of the readings.
Very good lecturer, and good supplementary materials/notes available if you aren't able to make class. Very light work load.

genuinely one of the best professors i've ever had. dr. begby is a super engaging lecturer and ensures that everyone is clear on what he is explaining. really understanding and always willing to help in office hours. likes to really get into discussions, especially if you show an interest! encourages participation and is just an overall great guy.

The man!!!! coolest professor, absolute genius. encourages student participation and treats you as an intellectual equal while still making sure you leave knowing more. Super super nice, really funny, and very helpful during office hours, especially when developing your arguments for your paper. overall best prof, and pretty cool course. take him!

This rating is not so much about the professor as it is about epistemology. It is a very weird phenomenon that never once mentions 'wisdom' as a concept, hence, the subject material consists of trite machinations of what to believe, how to arrive there around some tacit assumption of the existence of morality. Follow the rules is how to pass

Cannot say enough good things about this guy! Literally the best professor I have ever had. Cares about all of his students and makes sure everyone is following and feeling good about the content. Interesting lectures and encourages participation, plus super helpful guiding paper writing. Funny too! Overall, fantastic prof!!
I  can only repeat it "get ready to read".  Was a fantastic survey of epistemology.

The irritating know-it-all of the class ruined what could have been a lot more group discussion. When someone cannot fathom that sharing their thoughts and opinions multiple times per lecture is superfluous, it hinders fellow classmates. Overall Begby is a great professor, however you may experience an unfortunate group due to the small class size.

Truly believes that what he says is useful and worth thinking about. The course covers material from historical nonsense to his own nonsense. Assigns papers that refuse to acknowledge that science has already proven their own claims wrong. Ends the course with social epistemology; You know, social psychology without the science or experiments.

Tom is an INCREDIBLE professor! This was his first time teaching Epistemology, so there were some hiccups along the way (i.e. scrapping our second paper). Regardless, Tom was always passionate, engaged, and accommodating. He communicates his expectations very clearly and ALWAYS puts the needs of his students first! I cannot recommend him enough!

Dr. Lauro tries his best to make the 3 hours lecture as tolerable as he can by making the lectures more engaging between peers. The textbook used is quite a hard read and the content is all over the place, but Lauro clarifies it a lot better in his slides.

Ik it's only week 3 as of writing this, but his 3-hour lectures are very engaging, he explains abstract concepts in a very clear way that makes me understand everything. I'm not even a philosophy major but this might be literally my favorite class right now
Gregory was a great prof with a good sense of humour. He had a passion for epistemology and he explained concepts clearly when the textbook couldn't.

Rosemary has a very dry, ironic sense of humor that makes her lectures interesting; it's a fun take on philosophy! She is very accessible for extra help, both for class material and for anything else you're interested in. Overall, she's a brilliant prof and I will definitely try to get more classes with her.
Rosemary is great. She's fun and she explains things in a way that is understandable for everyone. The grading criteria and the amount of required work is fair & the final is easy.
Just prepare to remember vocabularies and you will do fine. She's nice :)
I think she's insane. Insane in the membrane. But I love her approach towards philosophy.  And she's hilarious.

Much of your success on the midterms and in essays, as with most philosophy classes, predicates on whether you're able to engage HIS lines of reasoning in the written questions. This kind of philosophy relies especially on whether you can defeat an argument on its own terms. Read the book to understand, go to lecture to strategize for exams.

Nice guy, decent class. Found his lectures almost useless, as well as the textbooks. The examples he gives are good, but I found he didn't give a clear idea of the arguments and the lack of lecture material didn't help. Hard to follow scribbles on the board with his oral lecture. Test were easy, but the multiple choice was stupid.

Jill is great! Her lectures are very helpful and she is always open to any and all questions, whether it be during class or otherwise, and will answer them promptly and well. This is really important in a field like philosophy. She is also a very fun professor and, as long as you keep up with the reading, you'll find that she is a joy.

She takes what could be interesting material and makes it boring, and then she tests you on the most unimportant parts of the material. The class average on the midterm was below 50% and then she told the class how surprised and disappointed she was. I was not surprised, since she asked questions about things we hadn't even learned. Stay away.
No Comments

Not the most exciting lecturer. She also doesn't seem to understand the articles we looked at. Her midterm had a 40% average and the questions were totally bizzare. Her grading scheme was also incomprehensible -- A+ is 87% and above, but she said she would never give an A+. An A is 83-86, and so on, but a D is 50-60%. AVOID IF AT ALL POSSIBLE.

Nice prof, understanding of students, and straightforward. Lecture content for this class however is very long and heavy, can easily lose focus. The papers are okay, but grading is tough. Key aspect is review review and ask questions if you dont understand.

Jim is one of the best prof I met in SFU! He really cares about students and willing to answer questions outside the classroom. Jim is also willing to provide guidance for students to succeed. I got a C- in the first assignment and he really gave detailed feedback in it. Must take this prof in SFU!

Eccentric guy. Unusual teaching style. Cares about his students, though, which is an automatic "A" in my books. His teaching style just didn't mesh well with my learning style (I prefer a bit more structure) but honestly I think most people would enjoy his teaching.

Theres so much to say about Jim: -has some of the funniest hand gestures i've ever seen -makes things REALLY clear by putting it in layman's terms -will try his ABSOLUTE BEST to understand exactly what you mean. He does this through paraphrasing and it really makes you feel like he's trying to understand. -super accesible -attendance not mandatory

Epistemology, def not a GPA booster no matter the prof. He knows his stuff. I thought @ times he focused too much on one topic but that could be good if you didn't do a proper reading, speaking of, LOTS of reading to do - not easy. Engaging class, def has favouritism to girls. Expect a 'B' at most!
cares  a lot about what he teaches! very smart.
Bloody cool. Speaks in such complicated terms that it is hard to tell what hes saying, but in the end it all somehow makes sense. Very helpful, and a fair, if somewhat hard, marker.
